did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract:
Material in this collection relates to Congregation Beth Israel (CBI), one of the oldest synagogues in Connecticut, established in 1843. In 1936 the congregation moved from its previous location on Charter Oak Avenue in Hartford to its current synagogue on Farmington Avenue in West Hartford. The architecturally significant building is listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places. CBI is one of the largest Reform congregations in the Northeast.
Abraham Feldman, rabbi from 1925 to 1968, was prominent both locally as a civic leader in the Hartford community and nationally as an important figure in Reform Judaism. Stephen Fuchs served as Senior Rabbi of Congregation Beth Israel from 1997-2011. Following his retirement from Beth Israel, he served as President of the World Union for Progressive Judaism (WUPJ) and is a noted author.
The Archive consists of correspondence, photographs, birth and marriage records, cemetery records, minutes, reports, financial records, information regarding rabbis and cantors, sermons, architectural drawings and blueprints.
Of particular interest are documents related to the earliest days of the Congregation, construction of the Farmington Avenue building, and the Ladies Deborah Society, one of the first Hebrew Ladies Benevolent Societies. Several prominent Hartford citizens and leaders of the early 20th century were members of the congregation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Ladies Deborah Society items include photographs, scrapbooks, and the original bylaws in German (1857) for one of the first Hebrew Ladies Benevolent Societies in the United States, as well as organizational material through disbandment in 1989.

Collection also includes Yizkor Books (Books of Remembrance), general information about several individual members and families, as well as material related to major historical events such as the Civil War, the World Wars, the Holocaust, and the Civil Rights era.
Cemetery records relate to maintenance, plots, bills, and deeds for Congregation Beth Israel Cemeteries in Avon, CT on Jackson Street and in Hartford, CT on Affleck Street.
Information regarding rabbis and cantors includes sermons of Abraham J. Feldman (served 1925-1968), Harold S. Silver (served 1968-1993) and Stephen L. Fuchs (served 1997-2011).
Photographs include most rabbis and presidents from the 19th century to present, as well as general congregational activities and celebrations.

Architectural drawings and plans include detailed documentation for the 1930's construction of the current synagogue building on Farmington Avenue in West Hartford and the 1950's addition of the Silberman Chapel. The archive also has several items related to the original Charter Oak Temple in Hartford, CT (built 1876 and used by CBI until 1936); Charter Oak Temple is the oldest synagogue building in Connecticut. Also available is documentation of the CBI Austin Organ (1935), technically known as Opus 1853. It is a four-manual organ built by the Austin Organ Company, which has its roots in Hartford; it is the last four-manual organ made by the company.
